subject: Re: On PALM
msgSnippet: I believe there are two cases where we should use other examples from the lexical sets to demonstrate the sound of QS letters as the current choices need
messageBody:
I believe there are two cases where we should use other examples from
the lexical sets to demonstrate the sound of QS letters as the current
choices need additional explanation which is best dispensed with:

the lexical set PALM would be better exemplified by FATHER
the lexical set CURE would be better exemplified by TOUR


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Terry Smithwick <Tinyallen@...>
wrote:
>
> I pronounce 'L' (actually a pretty dark L) in Calm
> and Palm.
>
> I consider myself a pretty middle-of-the-road
> general American accent. I was raised as an Army Brat,
> so was exposed to *lots* of accents and dialects as I
> grew up.
>
> On another note, I believe these 'complexities'
> were already there, they just loom larger in the
> context of QS. I know I've become more phonemically
> aware!
>
> --- John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
> > Ron Cameron scripsit:
> > > Speak for yourself. In my dialect the "l" in
> > palm, psalm, calm, balm, etc., is pronounced. :-)
> >
> > Hmm. What dialect do you speak?
>
>
> ===========
> Never insult anyone by accident.
> - Robert A. Heinlein
>
